content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is unique and interesting.

I'm going to have to do some reading to make progress on this one.  Sounds like a really interesting idea, though.

A tiny suggestion is to make "This is not ASCII art!" boldface, if that's available.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle.  Very clear and reproducible.  Complex enough to require a thoughtful solution.

I'm trying out a solution for this puzzle. Very interesting!

I have a question about "Widen The Picture [test]".  My code stalls out because one area of the "partial solution" never reaches exactly one candidate patch.  The uncertainty means that the final solution is not reachable (with my code).

Have a look at the state of the partial solution and let me know how this ought to be resolved using the ruleset in your description.

Edit: https://gist.githubusercontent.com/LazyMammal/684dee1351b489997ce2aef31b2d31f1/raw/dc9fc2a31e2e7d24958cafbf226fe264a10856f5/TC07

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear description, where the fun is understanding WFC and how this is different.

This is the most interesting challenge I did here. I encourage anyone interested in this topic to try it out, although there is a lot to read before getting started.
Wow, this is the coolest thing ever. Never heard about it, thanks for bringing it in here!
I've added details in the problem statement to allow full reproducibility.  This is because different results can be achieved by collapsing the probabilities in a different order.
yeah, there is a lot of info and several links that need to be followed and studied in order to complete this fully.
Thanks for all your hard work digging into this challenge and for all the feedback to make it better.

The puzzle ought to be solvable just by following the ruleset in the description.  At the moment "collapse patches" is slightly under-defined.

I think you should add to rule #2 to define "collapse patches" in some way.  Perhaps you could say "if all remaining possible, overlapping 3x3 patches contain the same symbol in a block position, that block is constrained to that symbol".  Or however you would word it.

My previous code attempt was looking for entire 3x3 patches and would only "constrain" the block symbols when I had one possible 3x3 patch remaining for that position.

I now see that WFC is more focussed on the possible symbols in a block position (implied by the overlapping possible 3x3 patches).

Using the revised version of the "constrain" instruction I was able to resolve the partial solution for "Widen The Picture [test]".

Now my (naive) code attempt simply needs to be faster so it doesn't time out!
Thanks for taking a look Husoski!

validated with wrong input ... well done

please check width on prototype in grill's tests (maybe others)
Done, and I've moved it to the very first statement

This didn't bother me, it was intuitive to me by looking at rule 3:
3 * After a patch has been 'collapsed', collapse all [[symbols]] that are covered by the 3x3 patch.

because after this go back to step 2 if still uncertain symbols. 

so the loop goes 234, 234, 234 until there is one symbol left, I did have to debug for hours until I got it right :) But that was due to my inexperience in Python and numpy arrays.

But I understand this confusion, maybe it can be more clear.
